title: SurvBregDiv: Transfer Learning for Time-to-Event Modelling via Bregman Divergence
text: Accurate prognostic modeling central goal survival analysis. rapid expansion large-scale biobank initiatives—rich genetic, molecular, imaging, electronic health record data—created new opportunities improve predictive performance clinical epidemiologic research. However, datasets often exhibit limited effective sample sizes, high dimensionality, low signal--noise ratios, additional practical constraints including privacy considerations restricted data access. Integrating external information offers principled strategy improving model efficiency. Yet, classical data-integration methods typically rely assumption multiple datasets arise common data-generating mechanism. modern biomedical applications, assumption rarely satisfied. Misspecification due population heterogeneity can induce substantial bias, motivating development transfer-learning approaches explicitly accommodate -source discrepancies. Bregman divergence successfully applied borrowing information binary-outcome settings, extending ideas censored time--event outcomes nontrivial due right censoring limited nature available external survival information (e.g., predicted risk scores, fitted regression coefficients, hazard ratios without access baseline hazard). Beyond full-cohort survival studies, many biomedical investigations rely nested case–control (NCC) design alleviate burden labor-intensive measurements, high-cost data acquisition, destructive finite biospecimen assays. NCC design, small number matched controls sampled failure time, producing survival data analyzed conditional logistic regression applied matched risk sets. Despite practical relevance, existing methodology software supports transfer learning external information borrowing NCC designs. SurvBregDiv package addresses challenges providing unified transfer-learning framework full-cohort Cox data nested case–control designs. methods integrate external information privacy-preserving manner applicable low-dimensional settings high-dimensional variable selection ridge, lasso, elastic net penalties.

title: SurvBregDiv: Transfer Learning for Time-to-Event Modelling via Bregman Divergence
text: Transfer learning via KL/Bregman shrinkage Integrates external information Bregman divergence–based penalization, enabling adaptive borrowing heterogeneous data sources. Privacy-preserving external information use Operates summary-level external inputs—fitted coefficients risk scores—without requiring individual-level external data access. Heterogeneity-aware borrowing Accommodates population differences tuning-parameter–controlled shrinkage, selectively borrowing strength sources compatible. High-dimensional modeling regularization Supports penalized KL-integrated models, including ridge, lasso, elastic net penalties variable selection shrinkage. Flexible external information formats Allows external inputs form coefficients, risk scores, partially overlapping covariate sets. Built-cross-validation tuning Provides cross-validation criteria tailored survival outcomes, including C-index, predicted deviance, V&VH loss. vignette introduces core functionalities SurvBregDiv illustrates workflows low- high-dimensional applications.

previous_headings: Quick Start > Full-Cohort Cox Model with Bregman Divergence Integration
title: SurvBregDiv: Transfer Learning for Time-to-Event Modelling via Bregman Divergence
text: low-dimensional Bregman-divergence–integrated Cox model intended settings number predictors modest. External information—either form external Cox coefficients (beta) pre-computed external risk scores (RS)—incorporated Bregman-divergence penalization mechanism. tuning parameter eta controls strength information borrowing: eta = 0 reduces standard Cox model (external borrowing), larger values eta increasingly shrink fitted coefficients toward external information. Two specific divergence choices supported: Kullback–Leibler (KL) divergence, implemented via coxkl(), squared Mahalanobis distance, implemented via cox_MDTL(). formulations, optimal eta can selected cross-validation using cv.coxkl() cv.cox_MDTL(), respectively. illustrate workflow using built-low-dimensional simulated dataset ExampleData_lowdim, consists training set (100 samples) test set (2000 samples) 6 predictors. first extract training components: externally derived coefficients beta_external: generate sequence tuning parameter eta values via internal utility generate_eta() fit integrated model across grid:
code: data(ExampleData_lowdim)  train  <- ExampleData_lowdim$train test   <- ExampleData_lowdim$test  z      <- train$z delta  <- train$status time   <- train$time strat  <- train$stratum beta_ext <- ExampleData_lowdim$beta_external_fair eta_list <- generate_eta(method = "exponential", n = 50, max_eta = 10)

previous_headings: Quick Start > Full-Cohort Cox Model with Bregman Divergence Integration > Low-Dimensional Integration
title: SurvBregDiv: Transfer Learning for Time-to-Event Modelling via Bregman Divergence
text: KL divergence–based integrated model, use function coxkl(): squared Mahalanobis distance–based integrated model, use cox_MDTL(): Note squared Mahalanobis distance formulation requires user-specified weighting matrix via argument vcov. standard Mahalanobis distance settings, taken inverse covariance matrix coefficients. vcov = NULL, function defaults identity matrix. Users may instead supply external risk score vector: datasets containing tied event times, users may apply coxkl_ties() function, extends integrated Cox model handle ties. following example illustrates use Breslow method tie handling:
code: coxkl_est <- coxkl(   z = z,   delta = delta,   time = time,   stratum = strat,   beta = beta_ext,   etas = eta_list ) cox_MDTL_est <- cox_MDTL(   z = z,   delta = delta,   time = time,   stratum = strat,   beta = beta_ext,   vcov = NULL,   etas = eta_list ) RS_ext <- as.matrix(z) %*% as.matrix(beta_ext)  coxkl_est.RS <- coxkl(   z = z,   delta = delta,   time = time,   stratum = strat,   RS = RS_ext,   etas = eta_list ) time_ties <- round(time, 2)   # Rounding time introduces ties for demonstration  coxkl_ties_est <- coxkl_ties(   z = z,   delta = delta,   time = time_ties,   stratum = strat,   beta = beta_ext,   etas = eta_list,   ties = "breslow" )

title: SurvBregDiv: Transfer Learning for Time-to-Event Modelling via Bregman Divergence
text: function cv.coxkl cv.cox_MDTL performs K-fold (default 5) cross-validation choose integration parameter. supports four criteria: "V&VH" — V&VH loss "LinPred" — predicted partial deviance "CIndex_pooled" — pooled comparable pairs "CIndex_foldaverage" — per-fold stratified C-index example using default "V&VH" criterion:
code: cv.coxkl_est <- cv.coxkl(   z = z,   delta = delta,   time = time,   stratum = strat,   beta = beta_ext,   etas = eta_list,   nfolds = 5,   criteria = "V&VH",   seed = 1)

title: SurvBregDiv: Transfer Learning for Time-to-Event Modelling via Bregman Divergence
text: Objects model fittings (.e. either coxkl cox_MDTL) can visualized using S3 plotting method plot(). function displays model performance changes across eta–sequence used fitting. Two types performance criteria supported: "loss" (default; −2 × partial log-likelihood, normalized sample size) "CIndex" (stratified concordance index) Users may directly call plot() method visualize model’s fitted performance training data without providing additional test data. test set supplied, performance metrics computed using test set instead:  cross-validated performance curve hyperparameter tuning functions cv.coxkl cv.cox_MDTL can visualized directly using cv.plot():  solid purple curve displays cross-validated loss across different values eta. green dotted horizontal line marks internal baseline eta = 0, representing model incorporate external information. vertical dashed orange line indicates optimal eta value, cross-validated loss minimized. comparison purple curve green baseline shows whether borrowing external information improves prediction performance. Whenever purple curve falls green line, using external information (eta > 0) yields better predictive accuracy relying solely internal model.
code: plot(   cox_MDTL_est,   test_z       = test$z,   test_time    = test$time,   test_delta   = test$status,   test_stratum = test$stratum,   criteria     = "loss" ) cv.plot(cv.coxkl_est)

title: Conditional Logistic Regression (CLR) using Cox PH Core — clogit
text: y Numeric vector binary outcomes (0 = control, 1 = case). z Numeric matrix covariates (rows = observations, columns = variables). stratum Numeric factor vector defining matched sets. required    CLR; omitted, warning issued data treated one stratum,    defeats purpose matching. method Character string specifying tie-handling method, determines    conditional likelihood approximation. Choices "breslow", "exact", "efron".    Default use first match, typically "exact" preferred CLR. max_iter Maximum number Newton-Raphson iterations passed cox. Default 100. tol Convergence tolerance Newton-Raphson update passed cox. Default 1e-7. comb_max Maximum number combinations allowed method = "exact" calculation. Default 1e7.

title: Conditional Logistic Regression (CLR) using Cox PH Core — clogit
text: function implements CLR mapping specialized Cox PH model: binary outcome y treated event indicator (delta), event times (time) set 1, ensuring "events" tied. stratum argument acts matched-set indicator. three tie-handling methods (Breslow, Efron, Exact) correspond different approximations Conditional Likelihood. mathematically exact CLR results, method = "exact" used.

title: Conditional Logistic Regression (CLR) using Cox PH Core — clogit
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data(ExampleData_cc) train_cc <- ExampleData_cc$train  y <- train_cc$y z <- train_cc$z sets <- train_cc$stratum  # 1. Fit Conditional Logistic Regression using the Exact method fit_exact <- clogit(y = y, z = z, stratum = sets, method = "exact")  # 2. Fit CLR using the Breslow approximation fit_breslow <- clogit(y = y, z = z, stratum = sets, method = "breslow") } # }

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence (CLR-KL) — clogitkl
text: y Numeric vector binary outcomes (0 = control, 1 = case). z Numeric matrix covariates. stratum Numeric factor vector defining matched sets (strata). required CLR. etas Numeric vector tuning parameters. Controls strength external information integration. beta Numeric vector external coefficients. Used compute KL divergence penalty. method Character string specifying tie-handling method ("breslow" "exact"). Mstop Integer. Maximum number Newton-Raphson iterations. Default 100. tol Numeric. Convergence tolerance. Default 1e-4. message Logical. TRUE, prints progress fitting. Default FALSE. comb_max Integer. Maximum number combinations method = "exact" calculation. Default 1e7.

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence (CLR-KL) — clogitkl
text: object class "coxkl" (inherited coxkl_ties) containing estimation results eta value, including estimated coefficients, linear predictors, log-partial likelihoods.

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence (CLR-KL) — clogitkl
text: function maps Conditional Logistic Regression problem Cox Proportional Hazards model fixed event time \(T=1\) event indicator \(\delta=y\). utilizes coxkl_ties core engine perform data integration via KL divergence penalty. Method: method ("breslow" "exact") specifies form partial likelihood used. 1:M matched case-control studies, "breslow" "exact" yield identical results, "exact" theoretically preferable. \(n:m\) matched designs (\(n>1\)), results differ. External Information: Larger values tuning parameter eta enforce stronger agreement external coefficients beta. Standard CLR: Setting etas = 0 (including 0 sequence) recovers standard Maximum Likelihood Estimates Conditional Logistic Regression.

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence (CLR-KL) — clogitkl
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load the matched case-control example data data(ExampleData_cc) train_cc <- ExampleData_cc$train  y <- train_cc$y z <- train_cc$z sets <- train_cc$stratum  eta_list <- generate_eta(method = "exponential", n = 50, max_eta = 50) external_beta <- ExampleData_cc$beta_external  # Fit CLR-KL using the Breslow approximation clogitkl.fit_breslow <- clogitkl(y = y, z = z, stratum = sets,                                   eta = eta_list, beta = external_beta,                                  method = "breslow") } # }

title: Cox Proportional Hazards Model with KL Divergence for Data Integration — coxkl
text: objective function weighted combination internal partial likelihood KL divergence external information. Larger values eta place weight external information. eta = 0 corresponds standard Cox model relying solely internal data. function uses "warm start" strategy solution current eta used initial value next eta sorted sequence.

what: Cox Proportional Hazards Model with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty — coxkl_enet
title: Cox Proportional Hazards Model with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty — coxkl_enet
text: Fits Cox proportional hazards model integrates external information using Kullback–Leibler (KL) divergence, applying Elastic Net (Lasso + Ridge) penalty variable selection regularization. External information can provided : RS: Precomputed external risk scores. beta: Externally derived coefficients (converted risk scores internally). strength integration controlled tuning parameter eta.

title: Cox Proportional Hazards Model with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty — coxkl_enet
code: coxkl_enet(   z,   delta,   time,   stratum = NULL,   RS = NULL,   beta = NULL,   eta = NULL,   alpha = NULL,   lambda = NULL,   nlambda = 100,   lambda.min.ratio = ifelse(n < p, 0.05, 0.001),   lambda.early.stop = FALSE,   tol = 1e-04,   Mstop = 1000,   max.total.iter = (Mstop * nlambda),   group = 1:ncol(z),   group.multiplier = NULL,   standardize = T,   nvar.max = ncol(z),   group.max = length(unique(group)),   stop.loss.ratio = 0.01,   actSet = TRUE,   actIter = Mstop,   actGroupNum = sum(unique(group) != 0),   actSetRemove = F,   returnX = FALSE,   trace.lambda = FALSE,   message = FALSE,   data_sorted = FALSE,   ... )

title: Cox Proportional Hazards Model with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty — coxkl_enet
text: z Numeric matrix covariates (predictors). Rows observations, columns variables. delta Numeric vector event indicators (1 = event, 0 = censored). time Numeric vector follow-times (observed event censoring time). stratum Optional numeric factor vector stratified analysis. RS Optional numeric vector external risk scores. Length must equal nrow(z). provided, beta must supplied. beta Optional numeric vector external coefficients. Length must equal ncol(z). provided, used calculate risk scores. provided, RS must supplied. eta Numeric scalar. tuning parameter KL divergence (integration strength). Defaults 0 (external information). alpha Elastic Net mixing parameter, \(0 < \alpha \le 1\). alpha = 1 lasso penalty, alpha close 0 approaches ridge. Default treats variable group. group.multiplier Numeric vector. Multiplicative factors penalties applied group. standardize Logical. TRUE, z standardized internally. Coefficients returned original scale. nvar.max Integer. Maximum number active variables allowed. group.max Integer. Maximum number active groups allowed. stop.loss.ratio Numeric. Threshold early stopping based loss ratio. actSet Logical. TRUE, uses active-set strategy optimization. actIter Integer. Iterations active set refinement. actGroupNum Integer. text: y Numeric vector binary outcomes (0 = control, 1 = case). 1:m matched case–control setting, stratum must contain exactly one case. z Numeric matrix covariates (rows = observations, columns = variables). stratum Numeric factor vector defining matched sets (strata). unique value identifies one matched set. beta Numeric vector external coefficients. Required. Length must equal number columns z. used clogitkl / coxkl_ties construct KL divergence penalty. etas Numeric vector candidate tuning values integration parameter \(\eta\) cross-validated. values sorted ascending order. method Character string specifying tie-handling method used underlying Cox partial likelihood. Must one "breslow" "exact". 1:m matched sets, yield identical parameter estimates, "exact" theoretically preferable. tol Convergence tolerance optimizer used inside clogitkl / coxkl_ties. Default 1e-4. Mstop Maximum number Newton iterations used inside clogitkl / coxkl_ties. Default 100. nfolds Number cross-validation folds. Default 5. Folds constructed stratum level using get_fold_cc. criteria Character string specifying CV performance criterion. Choices : "loss": Average negative conditional log-likelihood (lower better). "AUC": Matched-set AUC based within-stratum comparisons (higher better). "Brier": Conditional Brier score using within-stratum softmax probabilities (lower better). Default "loss". message Logical; TRUE, prints progress messages fold-wise evaluation progress bars. Default FALSE. seed Optional integer seed reproducible fold assignment. Default NULL. comb_max Integer. Maximum number combinations method = "exact" calculation, passed clogitkl / coxkl_ties. Default 1e7. ... Additional arguments (currently ignored).

text: list class "cv.coxkl" containing: internal_stat data.frame one row per eta CV metric results chosen criteria. beta_full matrix coefficients full-data fit (columns correspond etas). best list containing best_eta, corresponding best_beta full-data fit, criteria used. criteria criterion used selection. nfolds number folds used.

title: Cross-Validated Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Integration — cv.clogitkl
text: matched case–control problem handled via clogitkl, maps Conditional Logistic Regression Cox model fixed event time uses coxkl_ties core engine. Cross-validation performed stratum level: matched set treated indivisible unit assigned single fold using get_fold_cc. ensures conditional likelihood well-defined within training test split. criteria argument controls CV performance metric: "loss": Average negative conditional log-likelihood held-strata. fold, conditional log-likelihood computed test matched sets using fitted \(\hat\beta\) corresponding training data; fold-wise losses averaged. "AUC": matched-set AUC based within-stratum comparisons. stratum, case score compared control scores, counting concordant/discordant/tied pairs aggregating across strata. Higher AUC indicates better discrimination. "Brier": conditional Brier score based within-stratum softmax probabilities. stratum, probability assigned member via \(\hat p_{si} = \exp(\eta_{si}) / \sum_{j \S_s} \exp(\eta_{sj})\), Brier score mean squared error \((Y_{si} - \hat p_{si})^2\) across observations. Lower Brier indicates better conditional calibration sharpness. returned object structure "cv.coxkl" objects cv.coxkl_ties, facilitating downstream code reuse.

title: Cross-Validated Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Integration — cv.clogitkl

title: Example Data for Conditional Logistic Regression — ExampleData_cc
text: Data-generating mechanism: Study design: 1:4 matched case-control study (\(m=4\) controls per case). Covariates: 6 variables (Z1–Z6) drawn correlated multivariate normal distribution. True coefficients: \(\beta = (1, -1, 1, -1, 1, -1)\). Set-specific effect: random stratum-specific intercept \(\theta_i \sim N(0, 0.5^2)\) added linear predictor; eliminated CLR conditioning. Outcome generation: Within stratum \(\), single case (y=1) selected probability proportional \(\exp(\theta_i + Z^\top \beta)\). External beta estimation: beta_external obtained fitting clogit separate simulated dataset slightly different true coefficient vector \(\beta_{\mathrm{ext}} = (0.8, -0.8, \dots)\) correlation \(\rho = 0.3\), using "breslow" tie approximation.

title: Example Data for Conditional Logistic Regression — ExampleData_cc

title: Example high-dimensional survival data — ExampleData_highdim
text:
Data-generating mechanism: Covariates: 50 variables signals Z1–Z6 noise Z7–Z50. Z1, Z2 ~ bivariate normal AR(1) correlation \(ho=0.5\). Z3, Z4 ~ independent Bernoulli(0.5). Z5 ~ \(N(2,1)\), Z6 ~ \(N(-2,1)\) (group indicator fixed 1). Z7–Z50 ~ multivariate normal AR(1) correlation \(ho=0.5\). True coefficients: \( eta = (0.3,-0.3,0.3,-0.3,0.3,-0.3,0,\ldots,0)\) (length 50). Event times: Weibull baseline hazard \(h_0(t)=\lambda
u\, t^{
u-1}\) \(\lambda=1\), \(
u=2\). Given linear predictor \(\eta = Z^	op  eta\), draw \(U\sim\mathrm{Unif}(0,1)\) set $$T = \left( rac{-\log U}{\lambda\, e^{\eta}}ight)^{1/
u}.$$ Censoring: \(C\sim \mathrm{Unif}(0,	ext{ub})\) ub tuned iteratively achieve target censoring rate (internal: 0.70; external: 0.50). Observed time \(\min(T,C)\), status \(\mathbf{1}\{T \le C\}\). External coefficients: Fit Cox model Surv(time, status) ~ Z1 + ... + Z6 external data (Breslow ties), place estimated coefficients length-50 vector (zeros elsewhere).

title: Example low-dimensional survival data — ExampleData_lowdim
text:
Data-generating mechanism: Covariates: 6 variables Z1–Z6. Z1, Z2 ~ bivariate normal AR(1) correlation \(ho=0.5\). Z3, Z4 ~ independent Bernoulli(0.5). Z5 ~ \(N(2,1)\), Z6 ~ \(N(-2,1)\) (group indicator fixed 1 internal train/test). True coefficients: \( eta = (0.3,-0.3,0.3,-0.3,0.3,-0.3)\) (length 6). Event times: Weibull baseline hazard \(h_0(t)=\lambda
u \, t^{
u-1}\) \(\lambda=1\), \(
u=2\). Given linear predictor \(\eta = Z^	op  eta\), draw \(U\sim\mathrm{Unif}(0,1)\) set $$T = \left( rac{-\log U}{\lambda \, e^{\eta}}ight)^{1/
u}.$$ Censoring: \(C\sim \mathrm{Unif}(0,	ext{ub})\) ub tuned iteratively achieve target censoring rate (internal: 0.70; external: 0.50). Observed time \(\min(T,C)\), status \(\mathbf{1}\{T \le C\}\). External coefficients: quality level ("Good", "Fair", "Poor"), fit Cox model Surv(time, status) ~ Z1 + ... corresponding external data (Breslow ties) using specified covariate subset; place estimates length-6 vector named Z1–Z6 zeros variables included.

title: Generate a Sequence of Tuning Parameters (eta) — generate_eta
text: Numeric vector length n containing generated eta values.

title: Generate a Sequence of Tuning Parameters (eta) — generate_eta
text: Exponential: values formed exponentiating grid log(1) log(100), linearly rescaling interval [0, max_eta]. Thus smallest value equals 0 largest equals max_eta. Linear: current implementation calls seq(min_eta, max_eta, length.= n) therefore assumes numeric object min_eta exists calling environment. exact strings “linear” “exponential” supported; values method result error eta_values never created.

what: Simulate stratified Cox PH survival data with flexible censoring, optional binary covariates, and optional ties — sim.cox.highdim
title: Simulate stratified Cox PH survival data with flexible censoring, optional binary covariates, and optional ties — sim.cox.highdim
text: Internal function generate time--event data stratified Cox proportional hazards model high-dimensional covariates, stratum-specific multiplicative baseline scaling, controllable random censoring. Event times generated inverse transform sampling using baseline cumulative hazard. model $$h(t \mid Z, s) = \gamma_s \, h_0(t)\, \exp(Z^\top \beta),$$ \(\gamma_s\) stratum-specific positive constant, \(h_0(t)\) baseline hazard, \(\beta\) coefficient vector. Supported baseline hazards: "exponential": \(h_0(t)=1\), \(H_0(t)=t\). "weibull": \(h_0(t)=\alpha t\) \(\alpha>0\), \(H_0(t)=\alpha t^2/2\). Censoring implemented $$T_{\mathrm{obs}} = \min(T, C, \texttt{max_time}),$$ \(C\) random censoring time drawn specified distribution calibrated approximately match target censoring rate. Supported random censoring distributions: "uniform": \(C \sim \mathrm{Unif}(0, c_{\max})\). "exponential": \(C \sim \mathrm{Exp}(\lambda_c)\). "weibull": \(C \sim \mathrm{Weibull}(k, \lambda_c)\), shape \(k\) specified censor_weibull_shape. "lognormal": \(C \sim \mathrm{LogNormal}(\mu_c, \sigma_c^2)\), \(\sigma_c\) specified censor_lognormal_sdlog. "none": random censoring; administrative censoring via max_time. Binary covariates can specified index via binary_idx. variables generated using latent Gaussian threshold model achieve desired prevalence approximate within-binary correlation controlled rho_binary. Specifically, \(B\) binary \(P(B=1)=p\), generated \(B = (L > c)\) \(L\) standard normal \(c=\Phi^{-1}(1-p)\). multiple binary covariates requested, latent variables generated jointly equicorrelation rho_binary. controls latent (tetrachoric) correlation; resulting Pearson correlation among binary variables constrained prevalence generally close identical rho_binary. ties=TRUE, observed times discretized ties_levels bins (based sample quantiles) replaced bin midpoints induce tied event/censoring times. Smaller ties_levels produces stronger ties.

title: Simulate stratified Cox PH survival data with flexible censoring, optional binary covariates, and optional ties — sim.cox.highdim
code: sim.cox.highdim(   n_stratum = 1,   n.beta,   beta_value_vec,   beta_idx = NULL,   mu_Z = NULL,   sd_Z = NULL,   stratum_size = 1000,   rho = 0.1,   censor_rate = 0.3,   censor_type = c("uniform", "exponential", "weibull", "lognormal", "none"),   max_time = Inf,   seed = NULL,   baseline = c("exponential", "weibull"),   alpha = NULL,   censor_weibull_shape = 1.5,   censor_lognormal_sdlog = 1,   binary_idx = integer(0),   binary_prev = 0.5,   rho_binary = 0.1,   ties = FALSE,   ties_levels = 50 )

title: Simulate stratified Cox PH survival data with flexible censoring, optional binary covariates, and optional ties — sim.cox.highdim
text: n_stratum Integer. Number strata. n.beta Integer. Total number covariates \(p\). beta_value_vec Numeric vector. True coefficients first length(beta_value_vec) covariates. Remaining coefficients (n.beta) set 0. beta_idx Integer vector NULL. Indices (1:n.beta) covariates nonzero true coefficients. NULL, defaults 1:length(beta_value_vec) (original behavior). Must length beta_value_vec filtering valid indices. mu_Z Numeric vector NULL. Mean vector continuous covariates. NULL, zero vector used. indices binary_idx, mu_Z ignored. stratum_size Integer numeric vector. Stratum sample sizes. scalar, recycled length n_stratum; vector, must length n_stratum. rho Numeric. Correlation parameter \([0,1)\) equicorrelation covariance structure used generate continuous covariates. censor_rate Numeric. Target random censoring rate \([0,1)\). 0, random censoring applied (administrative censoring via max_time may still apply). censor_type Character. Random censoring distribution. One "uniform", "exponential", "weibull", "lognormal", "none". max_time Numeric. Administrative censoring time. Observed time min(event, censor, max_time). seed Integer NULL. Random seed reproducibility. baseline Character. Baseline hazard type. One "exponential" "weibull". alpha Numeric NULL. Required baseline="weibull". Controls Weibull baseline hazard \(h_0(t)=\alpha t\); must positive finite. Ignored baseline="exponential". censor_weibull_shape Numeric. Shape parameter \(k>0\) Weibull random censoring censor_type="weibull". scale parameter calibrated internally match censor_rate. Ignored otherwise. censor_lognormal_sdlog Numeric. Log-scale standard deviation \(\sigma_c>0\) log-normal random censoring censor_type="lognormal". mean log scale calibrated internally match censor_rate. Ignored otherwise. binary_idx Integer vector. Indices (1:n.beta) covariates generated binary. Default none (covariates continuous). binary_prev Numeric scalar vector. Prevalence \(P(Z_j=1)\) binary covariates. scalar, recycled binary covariates. Must \((0,1)\). rho_binary Numeric. Equicorrelation parameter \([0,1)\) latent Gaussian vector used generate binary covariates. Ignored binary_idx empty. ties Logical. TRUE, discretize observed times induce ties. ties_levels Integer. Number bins used discretize time ties=TRUE. Smaller values yield stronger ties. Must \(\ge 2\).

title: Evaluate Survival Model Performance — test_eval
text: Computes predictive performance metrics stratified unstratified Cox models. Supports Loss, C-index, Integrated Brier Score (IBS), Time-Dependent AUC (tdAUC).

title: Evaluate Survival Model Performance — test_eval
code: test_eval(   test_z,   test_delta,   test_time,   betahat,   test_stratum = NULL,   train_baseline_obj = NULL,   criteria = c("loss", "CIndex", "IBS", "tdAUC") )

title: Evaluate Survival Model Performance — test_eval
text: test_z Matrix predictors test set. test_delta Numeric vector event indicators (1 event, 0 censored). test_time Numeric vector observed times. betahat Numeric vector estimated coefficients. test_stratum Vector indicating strata test subjects. Defaults NULL (single stratum). train_baseline_obj list containing baseline hazard function (typically get_baseline_hazard). Required criteria = "IBS". criteria Metric calculate: "loss" (Log-Partial Likelihood), "CIndex" (Concordance Index), "IBS" (Integrated Brier Score), "tdAUC" (Integrated Time-Dependent AUC).

title: Evaluate Survival Model Performance — test_eval
text: numeric value representing performance metric. Returns NA metric computed (e.g., events test set).

title: Evaluate Survival Model Performance — test_eval
text: "IBS", function predicts survival probabilities converts risk (1 - S). riskRegression fails provide pre-computed IBS, function manually integrates Brier score using trapezoidal rule.

title: Evaluate NCC Model: Loss and C-Index — test_eval_ncc

title: Evaluate NCC Model: Loss and C-Index — test_eval_ncc
text: z_ncc Matrix covariates NCC data (rows = subjects). case Integer logical vector (0/1) indicating cases. set_id Vector matched set identifiers. betahat Numeric vector estimated coefficients. criteria "loss" "CIndex".

title: Evaluate NCC Model: Loss and C-Index — test_eval_ncc
text: Numeric performance metric.
